ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Yes, typically a NEAT implementation will have some means of comparing new connections (and sometime s neurons) with all of the connections currently

Hi,

Yes, typically a NEAT implementation will have some means of comparing=
 new connections (and sometime's neurons) with all of the connections curre=
ntly present in the population as a whole. If this comparison results in a =
match then you can re-use the innovation number, otherwise you take the nex=
t free innovation number.

Therefore to achieve the same functionaility whe=
n running on multiple machines you would need to compare the new connection=
 with the complete population across all machines.

On the other hand I'm n=
ot sure the existing NEAT implementations strictly adhere to innovation re-=
use, e.g. rather than maintaining a hashtable of all connections it may be =
quicker and alomst as good to maintain a hashtable of the last N new connec=
tions, thus introducing the possibility of a new connection being allocated=
 a new innovation number even though there exists a matching connection els=
ewhere.

Colin.
